intro: Zygophyllum atriplicoides var. megacarpum, commonly known as the desert sandmat, is a perennial shrub native to arid regions of North America. It is characterized by its small, fleshy, green leaves that help reduce water loss in hot, dry environments. The plant produces yellow flowers in clusters, which are adapted for pollination by insects. Its fruit is a dry capsule that splits open to release seeds, aiding in its dispersal across sandy soils. This species is well adapted to extreme conditions, making it a resilient component of desert ecosystems.
